text:
I'm curious about your perspectives on working with competitors in a small industry. I know finding your niche is great as a competitive advantage. I seem to have one but it's making me feel a little uneasy.

I'm a few months into working as a freelance copywriter/content marketer in the b2b SaaS industry. I worked in event marketing at a niche health-tech SaaS industry before and left to have more flexibility after having a baby last year. My former employer wasn't interested in hiring me at first so I started working with a competitor who contacted me. They've been great clients. Now my old employer wants to work together - great! And I just got an email from another competitor requesting that I do some work for them.

I know this is probably a silly worry and I'm lucky to be getting leads when I'm relatively new. But I feel... disloyal to my old employer by working with other companies in their industry? Especially when they offered to hire me full-time again as a Copywriter, which I declined. Anyone else been here?

text:
>  silly worry
Agreed! Your owe you old employer nothing. Are they still sending you random bonus paychecks out of a sense of loyalty? No? Well then!

If a client doesn't sign an exclusivity agreement (along with a HEFTY premium), then you enjoy and leverage that niche. You may want to avoid bylines so that you lower the chance of drama, but otherwise don't hold back.

text:
<@U02MYNYNDEK> I think that does require a bit more finesse. If these are all local shops in a small town... maybe not. If these are big corps, hell yeah. Middle ground—sort of depends on how the politics of the industry work. If you position yourself as an agnostic NICHE-X expert, then I'd include known _names_ on a public portfolio for sure. Whether you showcase the work itself may need some throttling. I'd maybe summarize the projects, showcase results, and include enough detail that lets on that you know the space and the lingo. If people want examples, maybe have a few generic pieces available vs. actual work.

You want to be neutral party, so your own clients needs to know that you're not going to send a competitor an example of THEIR stuff to try and get more business :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Depending on the kind of niche you're in, I think it's sort of expected that you'll be taking on several clients in the same space. Now, I've declined to take work in only a few instances where the product was almost identical but positioned as competitors in the market (think Coke/Pepsi, but for a financial product.) I declined to take on work from the 2nd company that came to me, only because it would cause confusion for me when trying to keep brand messaging clear, and I really didn't feel like I could do my best work juggling both. But this was the exception. I also make sure my clients know that they aren't exclusive, not to expect exclusivity from me, and (in some cases) that I don't want bylines or my name on work that may show me as an "SME" or staff writer or similar. As it stands, there's one niche where I did a lot of work for competitors (all known to them), and when you googled my name for a few of those years, the first so many result pages were for all three competitors. It was a bit confusing for MY brand, so I tend to avoid having bylines now for that reason. Otherwise, if you've thought through how to handle the logistics, GO FOR IT!
